questions.text: A young hockey player sustained an on field injury to his shoulder. MRI revealed a tear of rotator cuff. All of the following are tests used for clinical examination of rotator cuff muscles except:
questions.solution:
Lachman Test:

  • A clinical test to examine the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) of the knee joint.
  • Considered more accurate than the anterior drawer test.
  • Procedure:
    • The knee is positioned in 15 to 20 degrees of flexion.
    • One hand supports the thigh just above the knee.
    • The other hand grasps the upper end of the tibia.
  • The extent of anterior glide of the tibia indicates the integrity of the ACL.

Option A - Jobe's test (empty can). Muscle testing against resistance shows weakness or insufficiency of the supraspinatus owing to a tear or pain associated with rotator cuff impingement.

Option B - Lift off test - The lift off is a test for detection of an isolated rupture of the subscapularis tendon.

Option C - Patte (hornblower) sign - The Patte sign is used to determine the strength of the teres minor.

Key Takeaway:

Rotator Cuff muscle named tests:

Supraspinatus - Empty can (Jobe's) Test

Teres minor - Horn Blowers test (Patte)

Subscapularis - Lift off & Belly press test

choices.text: Most common site involved is the spine

questions.text: All are salient features of myositis ossificans progressiva (child with heterotopic ossification) except:
questions.solution:
Myositis Ossificans:

Myositis Ossificans Progressiva (Fibrodysplasia):

  • Option A - Life expectancy is reduced, often due to lung disease.
  • Option B - It is also known as fibrodysplasia and not fibromyalgia.
  • Option C - Involves deformities of the spine, hands, and feet.
  • Option D - Typically manifests in children before the age of 6.

Key Takeaway -

Fibromyalgia is Chronic condition that causes pain and tenderness throughout the body without specific causes. It is often associated with low pain tolerance and attention-seeking psychology.

choices.text: Calcific deposition in medial collateral ligament
Deposition is seen in tibial attachment of MCL
Steroid injection is given if very painful

questions.text: Pellegrini Stieda's disease; all are true except:
questions.solution:
Pellegrini-Stieda Disease

  • Overview:
    • Presence of calcification along the femoral attachment of the tibial (medial) collateral ligament.
    • Often related to trauma such as a sprain or tear of the tibial collateral ligament.
  • Treatment and Recovery:
    • Spontaneous Recovery: May occur without treatment; deposits may partially or completely disappear over time.
    • Intervention:
      • Local Anesthetic Infiltration: Provides immediate relief.
      • Supplementary Treatment: Injection of 40 mg of methylprednisolone (Depo-Medrol) or its equivalent can be curative.

Option A- Calcific deposition is seen in MCL ligament.

Option B- It may recover spontaneously as the deposits may disappear and become asymptomatic.

Option C- Deposition is specifically seen in femoral attachment of MCL.

Option D- Local steroid injection with or without local anaesthetic agent is done in symptomatic cases not responding to other treatments.

Key Takeaway -

Adolescent Knee Injuries

  • Pellegrini-Stieda Disease: Presence of calcification along the femoral attachment of the tibial (medial) collateral ligament.
  • Jumper’s Knee:
    • Avulsion injury of the proximal pole of the patella.
  • Sinding-Larsen-Johansson Syndrome:
    • Avulsion injury of the distal pole of the patella.

questions.text: A 45 yr housewife presents with pain in the dorsal aspect of distal one third of the forearm which aggravates while lifting heavy utensils in the kitchen and is relieved with rest and medications. Xray of the forearm are normal and finkelstein's test is negative. Probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Intersection Syndrome:

  • Condition: Inflammatory condition at the crossing of:
    • 1st extensor compartment (APL and EPB).
    • 2nd extensor compartment (ECRL and ECRB).

Option A - Radial Tunnel Syndrome:

  • Pain Location: Deep aching pain in the dorso-radial proximal forearm, 3-5 cm distal to the lateral epicondyle.
  • Cause: Compressive neuropathy of the Posterior Interosseous Nerve (PIN).

Option C - DeQuervain’s Disease:

  • Presenting Symptoms: Pain and tenderness at the radial styloid.
  • Clinical Examination: Finkelstein's test is postive, used for diagnosis

Key Takeaway -

It is important to differentiate between 2 closely related pathologies. Finkelstein’s test is typically positive in deQuervain’s tenosynovitis. Tenderness point in intersection syndrome is proximal to that in deQuervain’s tenosynovitis.

questions.text: Durkan's test is used for the diagnosis of:
questions.solution:
Durkan Test:

  • Purpose: Used to diagnose carpal tunnel syndrome (CTS).
  • Procedure:
    • The test is performed by applying direct pressure to the carpal tunnel area at the base of the palm.
    • The examiner uses their thumb to compress the area over the median nerve.
  • Positive Test Result:
    • A positive result is indicated by the reproduction of symptoms such as pain, tingling, or numbness in the distribution of the median nerve (typically the thumb, index finger, middle finger, and half of the ring finger).
    • The test can be used as part of a comprehensive diagnostic approach including history, physical examination, and possibly electrodiagnostic studies.
  • Sensitivity and Specificity:
    • The test has varying sensitivity and specificity but is generally useful as a preliminary assessment tool for CTS.

Clinical tests used in CTS

Option A - DeQuervain's tenosynovitis - The Finkelstein test usually is positive in this condition: "on grasping the patient's thumb and quickly abducting the hand ulnarward, the pain over the styloid tip is excruciating." Finkelstein stated that this test is "probably the most pathognomonic objective sign,"

Option B - Carpal tunnel syndrome - A carpal compression test (Durkan test), in which direct compression is applied to the median nerve for 30 seconds with the thumbs or an atomizer bulb attached to a manometer, was found to be more specific (90%) and more sensitive (87%) than either the Tinel or Phalen test.

Option C - Tennis elbow: COZEN'S test - Pain is aggravated by putting the extensor tendons to a stretch; for example, by palmar-flexing the wrist and fingers with the forearm pronated.

Option D - Golfer’s elbow – There is no named test for this condition. But clinically provocative tests can be done by fully supinating the forearm and passively extending the elbow, wrist and fingers which causes pain over medial epicondyle of humerus (common flexor origin).

Key Takeaway -

Carpal Tunnel Syndrome test:

  • Durkan test - Most specific
  • Tinel sign
  • Phalen & Reverse Phalen test

questions.text: Which of the following is not supplied by the median nerve?
questions.solution:
Major Motor Branches of the Median Nerve

Forearm Muscles:

  • Flexor Muscles: Most of the flexor muscles in the forearm are innervated by the median nerve, including:
    • Superficial Layer: Pronator Teres, Flexor Carpi Radialis, Palmaris Longus, Flexor Digitorum Superficialis.
    • Deep Layer: Flexor Digitorum Profundus (lateral half), Flexor Pollicis Longus, Pronator Quadratus.

Hand Muscles:

  • Thenar Muscles: These muscles are responsible for thumb movement.
    • Abductor Pollicis Brevis
    • Flexor Pollicis Brevis
    • Opponens Pollicis
  • 1st and 2nd lumbricals

Option A, B and C – FDS, Abductor pollicis and Palmaris longus – All of these are supplied by median nerve.

Key takeaway:

  • Thenar Muscle - FPB, Oppones Policis & Abductor Pollicis are supplied by the median nerve.
  • Adductor pollicis is supplied by the ulnar nerve.

questions.text: A 70 yr old lady presents with complaints of easy fatigability and back pain. Her DEXA scan shows T score of -3.5 SD. Which bone is most commonly fractured in this condition?
questions.solution:
Osteoporosis and Pathological Fractures:

  • Condition:
    • Osteoporosis is a condition characterized by weakened bones, making them more prone to fractures.
  • Pathological Fractures:
    • Definition: Fractures that occur in bones weakened by disease, often from minimal trauma or even spontaneously.
    • Common Cause: Osteoporosis is the most frequent cause of pathological fractures.
  • Diagnosis of Osteoporosis:
    • Test Used: Dual-Energy X-ray Absorptiometry (DEXA) scan.
    • Measurement: Bone density is measured and reported as a T-score.
    • T-score Interpretation:
      • A T-score of less than -2.5 standard deviations (SD) is indicative of osteoporosis.

Options A, B, C and D-

Common pathological fractures due to osteoporosis are as follows:

Thoracic vertebrae >>> Lumbar vertebrae >>> Neck of femur >>> Distal radius.

Key Takeaway -

  • The bones most often affected in osteoporosis are the vertebral bodies (thoracic > lumbar). Other common fractures associated with osteoporosis are fracture of the neck of the femur and Colles' fracture.
  • DEXA scan measures T score and Z score. But only the T score is used as a quantitative measure of osteoporosis.

questions.text: All of these are contents of extensor compartment of leg except:
questions.solution:
Contents of the Anterior Compartment of the Leg

  1. Muscles:
    • Tibialis Anterior:
      • Function: Dorsiflexes and inverts the foot.
    • Extensor Digitorum Longus:
      • Function: Extends the toes (except the big toe) and dorsiflexes the foot.
    • Extensor Hallucis Longus:
      • Function: Extends the big toe and dorsiflexes the foot.
    • Peroneus Tertius (Fibularis Tertius):
      • Function: Dorsiflexes and aids in eversion of the foot.
  2. Nerves:
    • Deep Fibular Nerve (Deep Peroneal Nerve):
      • Function: Innervates the muscles of the anterior compartment and provides sensation between the first and second toes.
  3. Blood Vessels:
    • Anterior Tibial Artery:
      • Function: Supplies blood to the anterior compartment of the leg.
    • Anterior Tibial Vein:
      • Function: Drains blood from the anterior compartment.
  4. Other Structures:
    • Superior Extensor Retinaculum: A band of connective tissue that holds the tendons of the anterior compartment in place at the ankle.
    • Inferior Extensor Retinaculum: Another band that helps stabilize the tendons around the ankle.

Option A,B and C – All these structures belong to the anterior/ extensor compartment of the leg.

Option D - Peroneus longus and brevis belong to the lateral compartment of the leg.

Key Takeaway -

MNEMONIC for Anterior Compartment of Leg – Tall Himalayas Are Never Dry Places

questions.text: All of these muscles are supplied by radial nerve except:
questions.solution:
Course of the Radial Nerve:

  1. Origin:
    • Location: Originates from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus (C5-T1).
  2. Course:
    • Upper Arm:
      • Passes posteriorly in the radial groove of the humerus.
    • Forearm:
      • Emerges from the radial groove and passes around the lateral side of the elbow.
      • Divides into superficial (sensory) and deep (motor) branches.
  3. Branches:
    • In the Arm:
      • Posterior Cutaneous Nerve of the Arm: Supplies skin on the posterior arm.
      • Lower Lateral Cutaneous Nerve of the Arm: Supplies skin on the lower lateral arm.
      • Muscular branches:
        • Triceps Brachii (Options A,B)
        • ECRL
        • Brachioradialis
        • Anconeus (Options D)
    • Deep Branch (Radial Nerve):
      • Supinator
      • ECRB
      • Extensor muscles: After piercing the supinator it emerges in the posterior compartment of the forearm to become the posterior interosseous nerve, which divides immediately into branches supplying all the extensor muscles of the forearm.
      • Includes extensor carpi radialis longus and brevis, extensor digitorum, extensor carpi ulnaris, extensor pollicis longus and brevis, and abductor pollicis longus.
    • Superficial Branch: Provides sensation to the skin on the posterior aspect of the forearm.
    • In the hand:
      • Sensory: Provides sensation to the posterior aspect of the hand (excluding the fingertips) and the dorsal side of the thumb, index, middle, and half of the ring finger.

Key Takeaway:

Pronator quadratus is supplied by the median (anterior interosseous) nerve.

choices.text: Card test for dorsal interossei in ulnar nerve examination
Card test for palmar interossei in ulnar nerve examination
Card test for dorsal interossei in median nerve examination
Card test for adductor pollicis in ulnar nerve examination

questions.text: A 37 yr male gives a history of sustaining supracondylar humerus fracture which was treated with plating 3 months back. Since the injury he is not able to hold a card/paper in between extended fingers against pulling force. Select the suitable option.
questions.solution:
Ulnar Nerve Tests

Card Test for Palmar Interossei (Adductors) (mnemonics PAD) of the Fingers:

The Card Test is used to assess the strength of the palmar interossei muscles, which are supplied by the ulnar nerve and are responsible for finger adduction. (Option A, C)

Procedure:

  1. The examiner inserts a card between two extended fingers.
  2. The patient is instructed to hold the card as tightly as possible.
  3. The examiner then attempts to pull the card out.

Interpretation:

  • The patient can hold the card firmly indicating normal adductor strength.
  • If the card is easily pulled out, it suggests weakness in the palmar interossei muscles, which could indicate ulnar nerve injury.

Option A & C: Card test is done for palmar Introssei (Not Dorsal Interossei)

Option D: Adductor Pollicis muscle is tested by Book test.- Froment sign (flexion instead of abduction)

Key Takeaway -

Ulnar Nerve Muscle & test:

  • Froment's test/ book test: adductor pollicis muscle.
  • Egawa's Test: dorsal interossei (abductors). DAB
  • Card test: Palmar Introssei (Adductors); PAD

choices.text: Can be associated with cervical ribs
Extra bone between scapula and cervical vertebrae is the main culprit

questions.text: A pediatrician refers a child to an orthopedician with probable diagnosis of sprengel's shoulder from his clinical examination. On detailed examination and history, it is confirmed to be sprengel's shoulder. Select the false statement:
questions.solution:
Sprengel Deformity

Definition:

  • Sprengel deformity is a congenital condition characterized by the upward elevation of the scapula relative to the thoracic cage.
  • The affected scapula is often hypoplastic (underdeveloped) and misshapen.

Associated Congenital Anomalies:

  • Cervical Ribs: Extra ribs that originate from the cervical vertebrae.
  • Rib Malformations: Structural abnormalities in the ribs.
  • Cervical Vertebrae Anomalies: Includes conditions like Klippel-Feil syndrome, which involves the fusion of cervical vertebrae.

Key Features:

  • In 50% of cases, an omovertebral bone is present:
    • This extra ossicle connects the superior angle of the scapula to the spinous process, lamina, or transverse process of one or more lower cervical vertebrae.
    • The presence of this bone restricts the descent of the scapula.

Option A- Sprengel’s deformity is associated with cervical ribs.

Option B- It is a congenital anomaly and not a developmental disorder.

Option C- Omovertebral bone which is an extra ossicle is the main culprit.

Option D – Presence of extra bone restricts the descent of scapula resulting in upward elevation.

Key Takeaway -

  • Sprengel shoulder is also called undescended scapula, Congenital Condition.
  • Extra ossicle called omovertebral is mostly present
  • Often associated with cervical ribs and other rib malformations.

questions.text: Identify the structure fractured in the given image:
questions.solution:
Bones of the Foot

1. Hindfoot:

  • Calcaneus (heel bone): The largest bone, forms the heel.
  • Talus: Sits above the calcaneus and connects to the tibia and fibula to form the ankle joint.

2. Midfoot:

  • Navicular: Boat-shaped bone located medially in front of the talus. (Option D)
  • Cuboid: Cube-shaped bone lateral to the navicular. (Option B)
  • Cuneiforms (3 bones):
    • Medial cuneiform (Option A)
    • Intermediate cuneiform
    • Lateral cuneiform (Option C)
  • These bones form the arch of the foot.

3. Forefoot:

  • Metatarsals (5 bones): Long bones numbered 1 to 5, starting from the big toe (medial side).
  • Phalanges (14 bones):
    • Proximal phalanges (5)
    • Middle phalanges (4) - (Absent in the big toe)
    • Distal phalanges (5)

Key Takeaway -

Cuneiform Bones

  1. Medial Cuneiform:
    • Location: Medial side of the midfoot.
    • Shape: Largest, wedge-shaped.
    • Articulations: With navicular, first and second metatarsals, intermediate cuneiform.
  2. Intermediate Cuneiform:
    • Location: Central in the midfoot.
    • Shape: Smaller, cylindrical.
    • Articulations: With navicular, second metatarsal, medial and lateral cuneiforms.
  3. Lateral Cuneiform:
    • Location: Lateral side of the midfoot.
    • Shape: Smaller, wedge-shaped.
    • Articulations: With navicular, third metatarsal, medial and intermediate cuneiforms.

questions.text: All of the following are main cell types found in bones except:
questions.solution:
Bone cells: There are three main cell types in the bone. These are:

Option A - Osteoblasts: Concerned with ossification, these cells are rich in alkaline phosphatase, glycolytic enzymes and phosphorylases.

Option B - Osteophytes are bone spurs or outgrowths that form along the edges of bones, usually at joints. They are typically associated with conditions like osteoarthritis and are a result of the body’s attempt to repair itself in response to joint damage or degeneration. Osteophytes can vary in size and shape and may cause pain or restrict joint movement if they impinge on surrounding tissues. They are not seen in normal bone.

Option C - Osteoclasts: These are multinucleate mesenchymal cells concerned with bone resorption. These have glycolytic acid hydrolases, collagenases and acid phosphatase enzymes.

Option D - Osteocytes: These are mature bone cells which vary in activity, and may assume the form of an osteoclast or reticulocyte. These cells are rich in glycogen and PAS positive granules.

Key Takeaway –

Osteophytes are bone spurs or outgrowths that form along the edges of bones, usually at joints. They are typically associated with conditions like osteoarthritis and are a result of the body’s attempt to repair itself in response to joint damage or degeneration. Osteophytes can vary in size and shape and may cause pain or restrict joint movement if they impinge on surrounding tissues.

questions.text: A 1 yr child who just completed Ponseti's cast treatment for CTEV has been advised to wear CTEV orthotic shoes for maintenance of correction. All of these are characteristics of orthotic CTEV shoes except:
questions.solution:
Option D - Medial arch support is used for treating flat feet.

Methods for Maintaining CTEV Correction

Once the correction of Congenital Talipes Equinovarus (CTEV) is achieved, it's crucial to maintain that correction to prevent relapse. Here are the common methods used:

CTEV shoes: These are modified shoes, used once a child starts walking.

  • Before Walking: The splint is worn throughout the day to maintain the correction.
  • After Walking Begins: Once the child starts walking, the DB splint is worn at night while CTEV shoes are used during the day.
  • CTEV Shoes

CTEV shoes are specialized footwear introduced when the child begins to walk. These shoes are modified to maintain the correct foot alignment with the following features:

These shoes are typically worn until the child reaches 5 years of age, providing ongoing support during crucial developmental years.

  • Option A - Outer Shoe Raise: Helps prevent foot inversion.
  • Option B - Straight Inner Border: Prevents forefoot adduction by ensuring the foot remains in proper alignment.
  • Option C - No Heel: Avoids the recurrence of equinus by keeping the foot flat.
  • Option D - Medial arch support is used for treating flat feet.

Key Takeaway -

The following modifications are made in the CTEV shoe which are used until the child is 5 years old:

  • Straight Inner Border: Prevents forefoot adduction by ensuring the foot remains in proper alignment.
  • Outer Shoe Raise: Helps prevent foot inversion.
  • No Heel: Avoids the recurrence of equinus by keeping the foot flat.

questions.text: A 73 yr old lady presents with complaints of long-standing back pain and kyphotic posture of her upper body. The X-ray of her spine looks as follows. Which of the following will not be used for treatment of this condition:
questions.solution:
• The given x ray shows anterior wedging of vertebrae with loss of height and typical cod fish appearance hence she is having severe Osteoporosis

Medical Treatment of Osteoporosis:

The treatment of osteoporosis includes the following approaches:

  1. High Protein Diet
    • Many elderly patients suffer from malnutrition. Increasing protein intake may enhance the formation of the organic matrix of bone.
  2. Calcium Supplementation
    • Though its effectiveness is debatable, calcium supplements may benefit patients with dietary calcium deficiency.
  3. Androgens
    • Androgens have an anabolic effect on the protein matrix of bone and can help reduce symptoms in some cases.
  4. Estrogens (Option D)
    • Estrogens have been shown to prevent further bone mass loss, particularly in postmenopausal osteoporosis.
  5. Vitamin D
    • Administered to boost calcium absorption from the gut, complementing other treatments.
  6. Fluoride
    • Although still under research, fluoride is believed to increase bone crystallinity, slowing bone resorption.
  7. Alendronate
    • Taken once daily on an empty stomach. It is effective but can cause esophagitis as a side effect.
  8. Calcitonin
    • Given via injection, calcitonin helps build bone mass and relieves pain.
  9. Teriparatide (Option A)
    • An anabolic agent that increases osteoblastic activity, leading to new bone formation.
  10. Denosumab (Option B) and Strontium
    • These are antiresorptive agents used to reduce bone resorption.
  • Option A, B & D: Teriparatide, Denosumab and estrogen all 3 are used in managing Osteoporosis.
  • Option C: Methotrexate has no role in management of Osteoporosis. It’s used in Rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Key Takeaway -
    • The given x ray shows anterior wedging of vertebrae with loss of height and typical cod fish appearance hence she is having severe Osteoporosis
    • Teriparatide is frequently used these days for increasing healing potential of bones after complex/ segmental fractures.
    • Calcitonin can be easily administered through nasal inhalation and has shown good results.

questions.text: Identify the object in the given image:
questions.solution:
Dynamic cock up splint –

A dynamic cock-up splint supports wrist extension while allowing finger movement, commonly used for conditions like wrist drop, radial nerve palsy, or post-stroke rehabilitation.

Features:

  • Spring Mechanism:Assists wrist extension.
  • Adjustable Support:Customizable wrist angle.
  • Functional Design:Stabilizes the wrist while enabling hand movement.

This splint aids in rehabilitation by promoting muscle re-education and preventing contractures, improving daily function as the flexor muscles work well to passively extend the wrist and fingers after active flexion using springs and rubber bands.

Use:

  • Radial nerve injurycommonly occurs in humeral shaft fractures especially at the junction of middle and lower thirds of the shaft called the Holstein-Lewis fractures. Most of these injuries are neuropraxia injuries and do not warrant any urgent/active intervention.
  • Radial nerve injury results in wrist and finger drop. Hence Cock-up or Dynamic cock up splints are advised till recovery is achieved to keep the wrist in extension.
  • Dynamic splint gives added advantage of passive finger extensionafter active flexion hence preventing contractures.

Incorrect options-

Option A: Cock up splint – Also used in radial nerve palsy. It just keeps the wrist and finger extended. No moving parts are involved.

Option B: VIC splint – Helps to release contracture gradually in VIC.

Key Takeaway -

  • Radial nerve injurycommonly occurs in humeral shaft fractures especially at the junction of middle and lower thirds of the shaft called the Holstein-Lewis fractures. Most of these injuries are neuropraxia injuries and do not warrant any urgent/active intervention.
  • Radial nerve injury results in wrist and finger drop. Hence Cock-up or Dynamic cock up splints are advised till recovery is achieved to keep the wrist in extension.
  • Dynamic splint gives added advantage of passive finger extension after active flexion hence preventing contractures.

questions.text: Which pulley is involved in etiopathogenesis of trigger finger?
questions.solution:
Pulley System in the Hand

The pulley system in the hand is essential for the proper function of the flexor tendons. It ensures smooth tendon movement and prevents issues like bowstringing.

Digital Flexor Tendon Sheath:

  • Annular Pulleys: Five annular pulleys (A1–A5) secure the tendons and prevent them from bowstringing.
    • (Option B) A2 and A4 Pulleys: Crucial for preventing flexor tendon bowstringing.
    • (Option A) A1 Pulley: Often involved in trigger finger, a condition where the finger gets stuck in a bent position.
  • (Option C and D) Cruciate Pulleys: Three cruciate pulleys (C1–C3) support the tendons by providing additional stability.

Option B: A2 and A4 Pulleys are Crucial for preventing flexor tendon bowstringing.

Option C and D: They are Cruciate Pulleys: Three cruciate pulleys (C1–C3) support the tendons by providing additional stability.

Key Takeaway:

Pulley and Significance:

  • A1: involved in trigger finger
  • A2: preventing flexor tendon bowstringing.
  • C1-C3: Cruciate Pulleys providing stability.

questions.text: All of the following are markers of bone formation except:
questions.solution:
Bone Formation Markers

  1. Osteocalcin
    • Function: A protein secreted by osteoblasts that binds calcium and aids in bone mineralization.
    • Clinical Use: Indicates osteoblastic activity and bone formation. Elevated levels are used to assess conditions like osteoporosis and monitor treatment efficacy.
    • Normal Levels: Varies by age, sex, and assay methods. Higher levels suggest increased bone formation.
  2. Osteonectin
    • Function: A glycoprotein that binds collagen and hydroxyapatite, aiding in bone mineralization and matrix organization.
    • Clinical Use: Reflects bone metabolism changes, though less commonly used in routine practice compared to other markers.
    • Normal Levels: Varies; typically assessed in research rather than clinical settings.
  3. Bone-Specific Alkaline Phosphatase (BSAP)
    • Function: An enzyme produced by osteoblasts that facilitates bone mineralization by breaking down phosphate compounds.
    • Clinical Use: Indicates bone formation rates and is used to diagnose and monitor diseases like osteoporosis and Paget’s disease.
    • Normal Levels: Reference ranges vary, with elevated levels indicating increased osteoblastic activity.

These markers provide essential information about bone formation, health, and the effectiveness of treatments for bone disorders.

Option A, B & C: Serum bone specific ALP, Serum osteonectin, Serum osteocalcin all 3 are markers of Bone Formation.

Option D: Serum N and C telopeptides are markers for bone resorption.

Key Takeaway -

Markers of bone formation: Mnemonic – BONC

  • Bone-specific ALP, (alkaline phosphate)
  • Osteocalcin/nectin,
  • N & C terminal propeptide of type I Collagen

choices.text: Stage of hematoma >>> stage of modelling >>> stage of granulation >>> stage of remodelling >>> stage of callus
Stage of hematoma >>> stage of granulation >>> stage of callus >>> stage of modelling >>> stage of remodelling
Stage of hematoma >>> stage of granulation >>> stage of callus >>> stage of remodelling >>> stage of modelling
Stage of hematoma >>> stage of callus >>> stage of remodelling >>> stage of modelling >>> stage of granulation.

questions.text: Identify the correct order of stages of bone healing:
questions.solution:
Stages of Bone Healing (Option C- Correct sequence)

Options A, B and D: They have the wrong sequence of stages hence incorrect.

Key Takeaway -

Stages of Fracture Healing:

  • Stage of hematoma
  • stage of granulation
  • stage of callus
  • stage of remodelling
  • stage of modelling.

questions.text: Which of the following fracture patterns has the least healing potential?
questions.solution:
Healing potential - Spiral (Option B) >>> Oblique (Option A) >>> Transverse (Option C) >>> Comminuted >>> Open.

The healing potential of fractures generally follows this order:

  • Spiral Fractures: Highest potential for healing due to stability and more contact area.
  • Oblique Fractures: Good healing potential, slightly less stable than spiral fractures.
  • Transverse Fractures: Moderate healing potential; clean breaks can be challenging to maintain alignment.
  • Comminuted Fractures: Lower healing potential due to multiple fragments and instability.
  • Open Fractures: Lowest potential due to high risk of infection and drainage of fracture hematoma

Problems Related to Union in Open Fractures

  1. Bone Loss
  2. Loss of Fracture Hematoma
  3. Inadequate Vascular Cover
  4. Secondary Infection

Proper initial treatment, including wound care and infection prevention, along with adequate surgical intervention, is crucial for promoting successful bone healing in open fractures.

Option D: Open Fracture has the least healing potential.

Key Takeaway:

The healing potential of fractures generally follows this order:

Healing potential – Spiral (Option B) >>> Oblique (Option A) >>> Transverse (Option C) >>> Comminuted >>> Open.

  • Spiral Fractures: Highest potential for healing due to stability and more contact area.
  • Oblique Fractures: Good healing potential, slightly less stable than spiral fractures.
  • Transverse Fractures: Moderate healing potential; clean breaks can be challenging to maintain alignment.
  • Comminuted Fractures: Lower healing potential due to multiple fragments and instability.
  • Open Fractures: Lowest potential due to high risk of infection and drainage of fracture hematoma.

choices.text: Upper tibia is the most common site
Weights upto 3-4 kg can be applied
Traction is given by inserting ST pin through the bone
Can be used for longer duration

questions.text: A 33 yr male patient sustained poly-trauma injury with subtrochanteric femur fracture and was stabilized with skeletal traction. Select incorrect statement amongst the following:
questions.solution:
Skeletal Traction:

Definition: Skeletal traction is a treatment method used to align and stabilize fractured bones by applying continuous pulling force directly through the bone.

Key Features:

  1. Purpose:
    • Used for managing fractures that require prolonged and strong stabilization.
    • Commonly applied in cases of complex fractures, particularly in the femur, tibia, or cervical spine.
  2. Application:
    • A pin or wire (e.g., Steinmann pin, Denham pin) (Option C) is surgically inserted through the bone.
    • The pulling force is applied via a weight system attached to the pin.
  1. Common Sites:
    • Upper tibia (Option A)
    • Femur
    • Cervical spine
  2. Force Permitted:
    • Can handle weights up to 7-8 kg (Option B), depending on the patient’s needs and bone condition.
  3. Duration:
    • Designed for long-term treatment until the bone heals or is ready for further surgical intervention. (Option D)
  4. Indications:
    • Severe or unstable fractures.
    • Complex fracture alignments that cannot be managed with skin traction.

Advantages:

  • Provides precise and stable alignment.
  • Effective for fractures needing substantial force.

Considerations:

  • Invasive procedure with a higher risk of complications like infection at the pin site.

Option A, C & D: Upper tibia is the most common site, Traction is given by inserting ST pin through the bone and Can be used for longer duration all three are Correct Statements.

Option B: Patient Can handle weights up to 7-8 kg, depending on the patient’s needs and bone condition. Hence Option B is False.


Key Takeaway -

Skeletal Traction:

  • Through the Steiman pin in the upper tibia used in Adults.
  • Upto 7-8 Kg
  • For longer Duration

choices.text: Soft cushion foot sole/ heel pad

questions.text: Select correct option about treatment for plantar fasciitis:x
questions.solution:
Plantar Fasciitis is a common condition that causes pain in the heel. It is primarily due to inflammation of the plantar fascia (plantar aponeurosis) at its attachment on the calcaneal tuberosity.

Key Characteristics:

  1. Cause and Pathophysiology:
    • The condition is a result of inflammation where the plantar fascia attaches to the tuberosity of the calcaneus (heel bone).
    • Repeated strain can cause small tears in the fascia, leading to pain and swelling.
  2. Symptoms:
    • Pain Characteristics: The pain is typically sharp and most severe in the morning with the first few steps. It may improve after some activity but can return after prolonged standing or sitting.
    • Tenderness: On examination, there is significant tenderness over the medial aspect of the calcaneal tuberosity at the plantar fascia’s attachment site.
  1. Diagnostic Findings:
    • X-Ray Features: In some cases, an X-ray may reveal a sharp bone spur projecting forwards from the calcaneal tuberosity. This "heel spur" is often associated with plantar fasciitis but is not the cause of the pain.
  2. Management and Treatment:
    • Conservative Treatments:
      • Analgesics: Pain relief with non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs).
      • Heel Pads: Cushioning the heel with a soft pad to reduce strain on the fascia. (Option A)
      • Ice Fomentation: Applying ice to the affected area helps reduce inflammation. (Option B)
    • Steroid Injections: Local corticosteroid injections can be effective in providing relief in cases that do not respond to conservative management. (Option C)
  3. Prognosis:
    • Most cases improve with conservative treatment over time, though the condition can be persistent and may require continued management.

Key Takeaway –

Plantar Fasciitis key points:

  • Pain: Typically worst in the morning, improving with activity.
  • Examination: Marked tenderness over the medial heel at the fascia attachment.
  • X-Ray: May show a bone spur at the heel, although it’s not the primary cause of pain.
  • Treatment: Includes analgesics, heel pads, ice therapy, and corticosteroid injections.

questions.text: Fill in the blank: __________is used for quantitative assessment of osteoporosis on a DEXA scan according to WHO.
questions.solution:
Osteoporosis: Osteoporosis is a systemic skeletal disease characterized by low bone mass and deterioration of bone tissue, leading to increased bone fragility and a higher risk of fractures. The bone condition is often diagnosed using a DEXA scan, which measures bone mineral density (BMD).

DEXA Scan:

  • Full Form: DEXA stands for Dual-Energy X-ray Absorptiometry.
  • Purpose: The DEXA scan is the most commonly used method to measure bone mineral density (BMD) and assess bone health.
  • How it Works: The scan uses two low-energy X-ray beams to measure the density of bones, typically at the hip and spine. It is quick, painless, and involves minimal radiation exposure.
  • Key Usage: Primarily used for diagnosing osteoporosis and assessing fracture risk, especially in postmenopausal women and elderly individuals.

T-Score

The T-score compares an individual's bone density to the optimal bone density of a healthy young adult (ages 20-29). It indicates how much higher or lower your bone density is compared to this standard.

  • WHO Diagnostic Criteria for Osteoporosis:
    • A T-score of -1.0 or above: Normal bone density.
    • A T-score between -1.0 and -2.5: Indicates low bone mass (osteopenia).
    • A T-score of -2.5 or below: Diagnostic of osteoporosis. (Option A)

If the BMD measurement is more than or equal to 2.5 standard deviations below the young adult reference value (T-score ≤ -2.5), the individual is diagnosed with osteoporosis.

Option B: A Z-score compares a person’s bone density to others of the same age, sex, and body size. It helps identify if factors other than aging are causing bone loss. A Z-score of -2.0 or lower suggests the need for further investigation. The Z-score is particularly relevant for younger individuals, men, and premenopausal women, where age-matched comparisons provide more accurate insights.

Option C: there is no such assessment score called O score.

Option D: calcium scoring is done in coronary arteries through CT scan to assess the level of calcification.

Key Takeaway –

A DEXA scan is the gold standard for diagnosing osteoporosis, based on WHO criteria using the T-score which Compares BMD to Younger healthy individuals aged 20-29 years. A T-score of -2.5 or below is Diagnostic of osteoporosis.

choices.text: Also known as marble bone disease
Affected bone becomes thick and spongy
The disease has a malignant potential

questions.text: A 43 yr gentleman with complaints of dull aching pain and swelling in thigh and multiple lytic area on x-ray in femur bone was diagnosed with Paget's disease. Which statement is false?
questions.solution:
Osteopetrosis Is Also known as marble bone disease so Option A is False.

Paget's Disease (Osteitis Deformans) is a chronic bone disorder characterized by the progressive thickening (Option B) and deformity of one or more bones.

Types of Paget's Disease

  1. Monostotic Paget's Disease:
    • Description: Affects only one bone.
    • Common Sites: Often the tibia or femur.
    • Features: less severe compared to polyostotic forms.
  2. Polyostotic Paget's Disease:
    • Description: Involves multiple bones.
    • Common Sites: Frequently affects the pelvis, spine, femur, and skull.
    • Features: Symptoms can be more widespread, including bone deformities, pain, and complications like fractures.

Key Features:

  • Bone Changes:
    • Initially, bones become soft and spongy.
    • Over time, bones become dense but irregular in structure.
  • Commonly Affected Bone:
    • Tibia is the most frequently affected bone.
  • Cause:
    • The exact cause is unknown, but it is associated with defects in osteoclast function, leading to irregular bone resorption and increased bone turnover.
  • Age of Onset:
    • Typically begins after the age of 40.
  • Symptoms:
    • Dull pain in the affected bone(s).
    • Bowing and thickening of the affected bone(s).
  • Diagnostic Findings:
    • X-Rays: Reveal multiple confluent lytic areas with interspersed new bone formation.
    • Bone Scan: Shows increased uptake of the radiotracer.
    • Serum Alkaline Phosphatase: Elevated levels indicate increased bone turnover.
  • Complications:
    • Pathological fractures.
    • Potential for malignant transformation. (Option C)
  • Treatment:
    • First Line: Bisphosphonates. (Option D)
    • Second Line: Calcitonin.

Option A: Osteopetrosis Is Also known as marble bone disease so Option A is False.

Option B, C & D: Affected bones are thick & spongy, Premalignant and Treatment with alendronate all three are Correct Statements.

Key Takeaway -

  • Marble bone disease – Osteopetrosis
  • Brittle bone disease – Osteogenesis imperfecta
  • Osteitis deformans – Paget’s disease

questions.text: Match the following splints with their uses:
questions.solution:
Option A: Aeroplane Splint

  • Definition: An orthopedic splint that resembles an airplane wing which immobilizes and supports the shoulder, upper arm, and elbow.
  • Purpose: Stabilizes and supports the arm, particularly for humeral fractures, shoulder dislocations, and post rotator cuff and shoulder stabilisation surgery.
  • Application: Applied with the arm in a neutral or slightly abducted position, secured with straps or Velcro.
  • Advantages: Effective immobilization, comfortable, and adjustable.
  • Disadvantages: Bulky and uncomfortable, may cause skin issues with prolonged use.

Option B: Knuckle Bender Splint

  • Definition: A splint designed to immobilize the fingers or hand while allowing the wrist to remain mobile.
  • Purpose: Used to treat finger fractures, prevent clawing and contractures post nerve injury, or post-surgical conditions by preventing unwanted finger movement.
  • Application: Applied to the hand with adjustable straps to ensure proper alignment and support.
  • Advantages: Allows for movement of the wrist, provides targeted finger immobilization, and is generally comfortable.
  • Disadvantages: May restrict hand function and requires regular adjustment to fit properly for proper use

Option C: Thomas Splint

  • Definition: A type of orthopaedic splint used to immobilize and support the thigh and knee, particularly for femoral fractures.
  • Purpose: Stabilizes the femur and knee, reducing movement to prevent further injury and aid in fracture stabilisation specially while transportation.
  • Application: Applied with the limb in a neutral position, secured with straps to ensure proper immobilization.
  • Advantages: Provides effective immobilization of the femur, reduces pain, and stabilizes the fracture.
  • Disadvantages: Can be bulky and uncomfortable in the perineal region due to metal rings; requires proper padding.

Option D: Dennis Brown Splint

  • Definition: An orthopedic splint used to correct hip dysplasia and congenital hip dislocations in infants
  • Purpose: Keeps the hips in the correct position to promote proper joint alignment and development.
  • Application: Worn continuously, usually for several months.
  • Advantages: Effective for treating developmental hip conditions, promotes natural hip joint development.
  • Disadvantages: Can be uncomfortable for the infant and requires regular adjustment and monitoring.

Key Takeaway:

Splint and Related Fracture:

choices.text: It is the counterpart of rickets in adults
It is a disease of deficiency of bone matrix
Can be diagnosed by bone biopsy from iliac crest
Looser's zones are characteristic x ray findings

questions.text: Select the false statement about osteomalacia:
questions.solution:
Osteoporosis is a disease of deficiency of bone matrix. Thus Option B is False.

Definition:

  • Osteomalacia is the adult counterpart of rickets (Option A), characterized by the softening of bones due to vitamin D deficiency.

Symptoms and Signs:

  • Bone Pain: Persistent pain in bones.
  • Muscle Weakness: Decreased muscle strength.
  • Spontaneous Fractures: Fractures occurring with minimal trauma.

Diagnostic Findings:

  • Bone Biopsy: Performed on the iliac crest to confirm diagnosis (Option C) >>> Characteristic finding: Excessive uncalcified osteoid.
  • X-Ray: Shows Looser's zones (pseudo-fractures) (Option D) as radiolucent areas at stress sites, commonly in:
    • Pubic rami
    • Axillary border of scapula
    • Ribs
    • Medial cortex of the neck of the femur
  • Treatment – Calcium and Vit D supplementation.

Option A, C & D: It is the counterpart of rickets in adults, Can be diagnosed by bone biopsy from iliac crest and Looser's zones are characteristic x-ray findings, all three are Correct Statements.

Option B: Osteoporosis is a disease of deficiency of bone matrix. Thus Option B is False.

Key Takeaway –

  • Osteoporosis Involves a deficiency in bone matrix whereas Osteomalacia and Rickets Caused due to deficiency in bone mineralization.
